pageContext.title: A company was sold at $100m in 20 months. Welcome to the crazy world of startups.
pageContext.content:
Dear readers,

Recently, our writer Jack Ellis told the incredible story on the fast rise and exit of Spin, a scooter sharing service built by three Singaporeans that was sold to Ford for US$100 million within 20 months (subscribe to read).

A Spin e-scooter near San Francisco’s Golden Gate Bridge. / Photo credit: Spin

We don’t know how much of the deal was done in cash, but with only one US$8m funding round announced so far, the valuation seems decent.

However, it’s the smallest of the three major scooter sharing startups in the US, so an exit at this point is wise. It may be their only move – given how capital-intensive on-demand transportation has become.

The story is yet another sign that we’re neck-deep in a crazy phase of the startup world right now. Massive and unprofitable private companies – many of them fueled by Softbank money – are flush with cash, spending on customer acquisition, and gobbling up smaller entities like never before.

Which leads to the question: How long will this last?

As you mull on that, check out our other recent subscriber-only pieces:

Thanks for reading, and I’ll see you soon!
